review.title: COEVOLVE: A Joint Point Process Model for Information Diffusion and Network Co-evolution
review.abstract: Information diffusion in online social networks is affected by the underlying network topology, but it also has the power to change it. Online users are constantly creating new links when exposed to new information sources, and in turn these links are alternating the way information spreads. However, these two highly intertwined stochastic processes, information diffusion and network evolution, have been predominantly studied separately, ignoring their co-evolutionary dynamics.

metadata.title: COEVOLVE: A Joint Point Process Model for Information Diffusion and Network Co-evolution

sections.text: For such a shared dynamic, we propose a point-of-time process model, COEVOLVE, which allows us to modulate the intensity of one process by that of the other. This model allows us to efficiently simulate interleaved diffusion and network events and generate traces that follow the common diffusion and network patterns observed in real networks. Furthermore, we develop a convex optimization framework to learn the parameters of the model from historical traces of diffusion and network revolution. We experimented with both synthetic data and data collected on Twitter, and show that our model offers good adaptation to the data and more accurate predictions than alternatives.

sections.heading: 6 Properties of Simulated Co-evolution, Networks and Cascades
sections.text: In this section, we conduct an empirical study of the properties of the networks and information cascades generated by our model. In particular, we show that our model can generate coevolutionary retweet and link dynamics as well as a wide range of static and temporal network patterns and information cascades.

sections.heading: 6.1 Simulation Settings
sections.text: During this section, we simulate the development of an 8,000-node network and the propagation of information across the network by selecting algorithm 1 on the basis of our model. We set the exogenous intensities of the linking event and diffusion event intensities to µu = µ = 4 · 10 − 6 or ηu = η = 1.5, and the triggering kernel parameter to ω1 = ω2 = 1. Broadly speaking, the parameter µ determines the independent growth of the network, the expected number of connections each user establishes spontaneously before T becomes µT. Whenever we examine a static property, we choose the same savings level of 0.001.

sections.heading: 6.2 Retweet and Link Coevolution
sections.text: Figure 2 (a, b) illustrates the retweet and link events, aggregated across different sources, and the corresponding intensities for a node and a randomly selected realization. Here, it is already evident that retweet and link creations are timed and often follow each other. Figure 2 (c) also shows the cross covariance of retweet and link creation intensity, calculated over multiple realizations, for the same node, i.e. if f (t) and g (t) are two intensities, cross covariance is a function of the time delay defined as h (τ) = х f (t + τ) g (t) dt. It is evident that cross covariance peaks at 0, i.e. retweets and link creations are highly correlated and coevolve over time. To simplify exposure, we have illustrated the coevolution using a node, but we found consistent results across all nodes.

sections.heading: 6.3 Degree Distribution
sections.text: Empirical studies have shown that the degree distribution of online social networks and microblogging sites follows a right of power [10, 1] and argues that it is a consequence of the fact that the rich are getting richer. A network's degree distribution is a right of power if the expected number of nodes md is given with degree d of md-γ, where γ > 0. Intuitively, the higher the values of the parameters α and β, the closer the resulting degree distribution follows a right of power; the lower their values, the closer the distribution is to an Earth-Renyi random chart [32]. Figure 3 confirms this intuition by showing the degree distribution for different values of β and α.

sections.heading: 6.4 Small (shrinking) Diameter
sections.text: There is empirical evidence that the diameter of online social networks and microblogging sites is relatively small and shrinks (or flattens) as the network grows [33, 10, 24]. Figure 4 (a-b) shows the diameter of the largest connected component (LCC) versus the sparseness of the network over time at different values of α and β. Although there is a brief diameter increase at the beginning due to the merging of small connected components, the diameter decreases as the network develops. Nodes enter the network here if they follow (or follow) a node in the largest connected component.

sections.heading: 6.5 Clustering Coefficient
sections.text: Triadic closure [34, 12, 35] has often been presented as a plausible mechanism for making links, but different social networks and microblogging sites have different levels of triadic closure [36]. Importantly, our method is able to create networks with different levels of triadic closure, as Figure 4 (c-d) shows, where we record the cluster coefficient [37], which is proportional to the frequency of triadic closures, for different values of α and β.

sections.heading: 6.6 Network Visualization
sections.text: Figure 5 illustrates several snapshots of the largest connected component (LCC) of two 300-node networks for two specific insights of our model, under two different values of β. In both cases, we used µ = 2 × 10 − 4, α = 1 and η = 1.5. The top two lines correspond to β = 0 and represent one end of the spectrum, i.e. Erdos-Renyi Random Network. Here, the network develops uniformly. The bottom two lines correspond to β = 0.8 and represent the other end, i.e. scale-free networks. Here, the network develops locally, and clusters arise naturally as a result of local growth. They are represented by a combination of forced directed and Fruchterman pure gold structure with Gephi1. This figure clearly illustrates that we can generate networks with a very different structure by carefully selecting parameters.

sections.heading: 6.7 Cascade Patterns
sections.text: Our model can generate the most common cascade structures as well as heavy cascade sizes and depth distributions as observed in historical Twitter data [25]. Figure 8 summarizes the results: The higher the α (β) value, the shallower and wider the cascades.

sections.heading: 7 Experiments on Model Estimation and Prediction on Synthetic Data
sections.text: In this section, we will first show that our model estimation method can accurately restore the true model parameters from historical compound and diffusion event data, and then show that our model can accurately predict network evolution and information diffusion over time, significantly exceeding two state-of-the-art methods [5, 3, 4] for predicting new connections, and a Hawkes process that does not take network evolution into account when predicting new diffusion events.

sections.heading: 7.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: During this section, we experiment with our model using m = 400 nodes. We determine the model parameters for each node in the network by taking samples of µ х U (0, 0.0004), α х U (0, 0.1), η х U (0, 1.5) and β х U (0, 0.1). Subsequently, we sample up to 60,000 link and information diffusion events from our model using algorithm 1 and on average over 8 different simulation runs.

sections.heading: 7.2 Model Estimation
sections.text: We evaluate the accuracy of our model estimation method using two metrics: (i) the relative mean absolute error (i.e. E [| x − x | / x], MAE) between the estimated parameters (x) and the true parameters (x), (ii) the Kendall rank correlation coefficient between each estimated parameter and its true value, and (iii) the test log probability. Figure 9 shows that the estimation becomes more accurate the more events we factor into the estimation method.

sections.heading: 7.3 Link Prediction
sections.text: We use our model to predict the identity of the source for each test link event taking into account historical events prior to the time of the prediction and compare its performance with two state-of-the-art methods, which we call TRF [3] and WENG [5]. TRF measures the likelihood of establishing a connection from a source at a given time simply by calculating the proportion of new links generated from the source in all connections created up to that time. WENG takes into account different linking strategies and makes a prediction by combining these strategies.Here, we evaluate performance by calculating the likelihood of all potential links using our TRF and WENG models and then calculate (i) the average value of all true (test) events (AvgRank) and (ii) the likelihood of success that true (test) events are among the top-1 potential events at each test point (top-1).

sections.heading: 7.4 Activity Prediction
sections.text: We use our model to predict the identity of the node that will generate each test diffusion event against historical events prior to the time of prediction and compare its performance to a baseline that consists of a Hawkes process without network evolution. For the Hawkes baseline, we take a snapshot of the network immediately before the prediction time and use all historical retweeting events to fit into the model. Here, we evaluate performance using the same two metrics as in the link prediction task and summarize the results in Figure 10 based on an increasing number of training events. Results show that our model performs significantly better than the baseline by modelling network evolution.

sections.heading: 8 Experiments on Coevolution and Prediction on Real Data
sections.text: In this section, we validate our model using a large Twitter dataset containing nearly 8 million tweets, retweets, and linkages of events from more than 6 million users [3]. We will show that our model can capture coevolutionary dynamics, thereby predicting retweets and linkages of creation events more accurately than multiple alternatives.

sections.heading: 8.1 Dataset Description & Experimental Setup
sections.text: We use a data set that includes both linking events and tweets / retweets from millions of Twitter users [3]. Specifically, the data set contains data from three users: the first group of users (8,779 users) are source nodes for which all tweet times were collected; the second group of users (77,200 users) are the followers of the first group of users for whom all retweet times (and source identities) were collected; and the third group of users (6,546,650 users) are the users who follow at least one user in the first group during the recording period for which all link times were collected. In our experiments, we focus on all events (and users) during a 5-day period in which users in the first group post 371,012 tweets, users in the second group retweet 130,275 tweets and users in the third group create 7,983,306 new links.

sections.heading: 8.3 Link prediction
sections.text: We use our model to predict the identity of the source for each test link event, given historical (link and retweet events) events prior to the time of the prediction, and compare its performance with two state-of-the-art methods known as TRF [3] and WENG [5]. TRF measures the likelihood of connecting from a source at a given time simply by calculating the proportion of new links generated from the source relative to the total number of links created by that time. WENG takes into account different linking strategies and makes a prediction by combining them. We evaluate performance by calculating the likelihood of all potential links using different methods and then calculating (i) the average value of all true (test) events (AvgRank) and (ii) the likelihood of success (SP) that true (test) events are among the top 1 potential events at each test point (top-1).

sections.heading: 8.4 Activity prediction
sections.text: We use our model to predict the identity of the node that will generate each test diffusion event, given historical events prior to the time of prediction, and compare its performance to a baseline consisting of a Hawkes process without network evolution. For the Hawkes baseline, we take a snapshot of the network just before the prediction time and use all historical retweet events to fit into the model. Here, we evaluate performance using the same two metrics as in the link prediction task and summarize the results in Figure 14 (c-d) against the background of an increasing number of training events. Results show that our model performs significantly better than the baseline by modelling coevolutionary dynamics.

sections.heading: 8.5 Model Checking
sections.text: Taking into account all the ti + 1 follow-up event times generated by a Hawkes process, the intensity integration measurements up to the time of the change in the theorem [13] should correspond to the exponential distribution of the unit rate. Figure 15 shows the quantiles of the intensity integrals calculated from the intensities with the parameters estimated from the real Twitter data against the quantities of the exponential distribution of the unit rate. It clearly shows that the points are roughly in line, providing empirical evidence that a Hawkes process is the right model to capture real dynamics.

metadata.abstractText: Information diffusion in online social networks is affected by the underlying network topology, but it also has the power to change it. Online users are constantly creating new links when exposed to new information sources, and in turn these links are alternating the way information spreads. However, these two highly intertwined stochastic processes, information diffusion and network evolution, have been predominantly studied separately, ignoring their co-evolutionary dynamics. We propose a temporal point process model, COEVOLVE, for such joint dynamics, allowing the intensity of one process to be modulated by that of the other. This model allows us to efficiently simulate interleaved diffusion and network events, and generate traces obeying common diffusion and network patterns observed in real-world networks. Furthermore, we also develop a convex optimization framework to learn the parameters of the model from historical diffusion and network evolution traces. We experimented with both synthetic data and data gathered from Twitter, and show that our model provides a good fit to the data as well as more accurate predictions than alternatives.
